The palace was almost completely destroyed by the Germans during WW II, but has been stunningly restored.Entrance to the park is advertised as being free, although the lady at the entrance by the Pavilion of the 3 Graces may want to sell you a ticket (150 R). Entry tickets to the palace proper (500R) are available from a booth to the left of the main entrance in the horseshoe-shaped courtyard. The palace is closed on Fridays. In contrast to Catherine's Summer Palace at Tsarskoye Selo, Pavlovsk is relatively uncrowded. When I was there, I practically had the whole place to myself.
another must see!. A beautiful park that is worth a visit when you are in St. Petersburg.

A nice change of pace.. If Rococo isn't your thing, the Great Palace in Pavlovsk offers something a little different. The style is much more sedate and "homey" than most of the other big tourist draws. You will also not be tripping over hoards of other tourists. There is a lovely library which I had to myself to explore. I also really enjoyed the park area. I believe it was the old hunting grounds and though there are some paths and out-buildings, it still has a more natural feel than the Tsarskoe Selo parks. I'm a Canadian but live in the middle east and really enjoyed the nostalgic feeling of seeing birch trees and tall pines. A lovely place for a walk on a fall day.

A more relaxed place to visit. Not as many tourists as the other palaces, probably because of the distance. But it's a much more human scale, and the gardens are well worth a stroll.Visit at the same time you're going to Catherine Palace
Impressive. We visited this palace after seeing Peterhof and Catherine Palace, so we were exhausted. However it was still quite beautiful; certainly not as opulent as the previous ones.

Excellent Second Palace to Visit after Catherine's. After our trip to Catherine's Palace, we had planned to visit Alexander Palace, the one where Nicholas II and his family lived and were imprisoned, but our guide suggested Pavlovsk instead. Alexander Palace is mainly a memorial to the last tzar and his family, while Pavlovsk is a suburb neoclassical palace worth seeing in its own right. A gift from Catherine to her son, it's much smaller than her palace, but in many ways, it is more liveable and comfortable. Yes, it has its public rooms which are beautiful, but it also has private quarters where Paul and his family lived. If you go to Catherine's Palace and have a choice of visiting a second one, we recommend Pavlovsk. (It also has an excellent cafe where you can have a bite to eat and some sit-down time between the two visits.)

dazzling and historic. this is a spectacular restoration of a palace wrecked during World War II. It has 2 floors of gorgeous rooms that aew a primer in neoclassical design. Reach it by the 545 bus from Moskoskaya.
Enormous nautural park. If you like strolling through parks, natural ones, this is the place for you. The palace meant nothing much to me.

Nearby the metro station , I immediately saw the "Monumentto to the heoic defenders of Leningrad , a high obelisk.By car , we did the route in around 30 minutes , and it was easy to park there.We started taking a walk at the magnific Pavlovsk Park that is not an urban park : I felt myself at a forest or something like that , full of green trees , birds , squiers , lakes...It was very nice to wander around there.Then , we reached the Pavlovsk Palace: from outside it didnt catch my attention at all , but inside it was wonderful. There are guided tours in russian though the fine rooms: Italian Hall, Grecian Hall , Hall of War , Hall of Peace , Paul´s throne room.

Pavlovsk Palace has many unique qualities. We went to Pavlovsk Palace as part of the "The Last Romanovs" excursion with Celebrity. We really enjoyed the authentic Russian lunch in the palace's restaurant - including the shot of vodka - prior to our tour of the palace. The rooms had so many unique qualities and contents. It was a very pleasant visit and the park was beautiful. There were horse drawn carriages you could rent to go through the park if you wanted to as well.

Pavlovsk Palace & Park. One of the nicest imperial residences we visited while on our shore day tours was a side trip of Pavlovsk Palace & Park located about 16 miles from St Petersburg - just outside of Pushkin. When taking the day trip to Pushkin make sure to plan time to visit the lovely palce of Pavlovsk and the park which is a gold and while palace built by Catherin the Great for her son Paul I (Pavel) in the 1700's. Pavel moved into this palace with his family of 10 children and they roamed through the 1500 acrea estate during the youth. Pavlovsk was never a "state palace" but was an actual home for this royal couple and the decoration and feel of the palace show you how much love and affection was present in this home. My grand-kids ages 18 & 21 loved Pavovsk Palace and we very much enjoyed our time spent touring the palace and walking the park after our visit to Catherine's Palace in Puskin. Thank you Red October USA for suggesting and make this wonderful day trip available for our enjoyment for without your suggestions we never would have found this lovely palace and park.

A must-see for palace fans. We went to Pavlovsk Palace as part of the "The Last Romanovs" shore excursion with Royal Caribbean. We had a lovely Russian lunch in the palace's restaurant, and then took a tour of the palace and the grounds. The rooms are breathtaking, and the grounds are lovely as well. Well worth a trip, especially for tourists who are fans of the royal palaces as well as history buffs.

The Most Beautiful and Interesting Palace in Russia. In October I visited Pavlovsk Palace just outside St. Petersburg with a group called Russia: Making Connections. It was the most incredible experience I've ever had and a very important trip for anyone interested in Russia art, architecture and history...and I really DID "make connections"!!!We learned about Pavlovsk Palace in depth, met with curators of the decorative arts, textile, painting/sculpture departments and other experts - including members of the restoration staff. As Pavlovsk was almost totally destroyed during World War II, that was a story in itself! Then, as part of the program, we visited five additional palaces in the St. Petersburg area to learn about the people who lived on these grand estates, to compare architectural styles and to learn more about Russian history. Accommodations were a real treat - provided in a lovely palace-turned-private-hotel and we felt like tsars and tsarinas in the midst of all this splendor.There was much to see within walking distance of "our palace". The parks in this area are stuff of dreams with pagodas, delicate footbridges over streams, wildlife, formal and informal gardens and vistas designed for an empress. During leisure time, we could set our own pace and choose activities based on our own interests - which I appreciated.I understand that an optional program to Moscow will soon be offered in conjunction with the Pavlovsk / St. Petersburg program and hope to do that also at some point.This was a remarkable experience and unique in that I really felt I had connected with Russian people, interacted with them, learned from them and, as a result, now share their pride and appreciation of their old and rich culture.
